scenes.location: THE GROUNDS OF WINDSOR CASTLE, FOREST
characters: LEAVE US ALONE, WHY DON'T YOU

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Begin on black.  The sound of rain driving into trees.  Something wipes frame and we are suddenly hurtling throug a forest on the shoulders of a wild-eyed, kilted JOHN BROWN.  Drenched hair streaming, head swivelling left and right, as he searches the lightening-dark.  A crack to hi left.  He spins round, raises his pistol, smacks past saplings and plunges on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close-up on BROWN as he bangs against a tree and heaves f air.  A face in its fifties, mad-fierce eyes, handsome, bruised lips, liverish.  He goes on searching the dark.  Stops.  Listens through the rain.  A beat.  Thinking he hears a faint thump in the distance, he swings round and races on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BROWN tears through the trees, pistol raised at full arm' length, breath coming harder and harder.  But even now there's a ghost grace, a born hunter's grace.  He leaps fallen branches, swerves through turns in the path, eyes forward, never stumbling once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BROWN bursts into a clearing, breaks to the centre and stops.  With his pistol raised, he turns one full slow circle.  His eyes take in every swerve and kick of the wildly swaying trees. There's a crack and a branch snaps behind him.  He spins round, bellows deep from his heart:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God save the Queen!! And fires. Nothing happens.  The trees go on swaying, the storm goes on screaming and BROWN just stands there, staring into empty space.  A pause. Slowly, he starts to frown as the fact begins to dawn on him that he is alone.  He stares at the thrashing trees, waving their mocking arms at him.  His hand lets the pist drop to his side.  He feels the rain drench down his face And now, for the first time, we see that his socks have fallen to his ankles and his knees are cut to shreds.  He shifts a foot.  His dress-shoes are covered in mud.  He goes on staring into the dark.  Nothing.  Just the wind and rain.  Gradually, we pull back, higher and higher.  As we do, we hear the quiet cultivated voice

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have sent for a Mr. John BROWN from Balmoral.  Her majesty has mentioned him, on one or two occasions, as being a most devoted outdoor servant to Prince Albert during his last days there... John BROWN is now just a tiny figure dwarfed by the storm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen is black.  As the camera pulls back, we discov that we are looking at a black night-gown. Queen VICTORIA is sitting at her dressing table, while an elderly HAIRDRESSER, also in black, works at her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... The depths of the Queen's sorrow remain impenetrable.  She has now restricted herself to a regime of such ferocious introspection that we are all at our wits' end...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bust of the Prince Consort is draped in black.  His des is laid out as if for work.  A VALET is brushing one of h suits before laying it carefully on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... The Household continues, at her instruction, to observe the rituals now so familiar to her, in a vain attempt to render vivid that which can never be revived... Close-up on a small table as a shaving brush is placed carefully beside a dish of freshly poured water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hairdresser is pulling VICTORIA's hair back into the widow's cape.  For the first time, we see her face.  It i set in a mask of severity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... It will not surprise you to hear that she continues steadfast in her refusal to accept any public engagements, however trivial...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bronze cast of Prince Albert's hand hangs above the Roy bed.  His sleeping-gown is laid out on one side. A somberly dressed middle-aged man stands by the bed: DOCTOR JENNER, the Queen's physician.  He is placing potions and medicaments in a row on the bedside table. Behind him, TWO MAIDSERVANTS are busy stripping and remaking the bed while another raises the window to air t room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Family and staff expend all their efforts endeavouring to draw her out of this state of unfettered morbidity, but to no avail.  Indeed, Doctor Jenner will not undertake to vouchsafe her sanity, unless some remedy is found...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICTORIA is turning slowly around as a young ASSISTANT DRESSER completes the fastening on her black crepe dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... We must hope, therefore, that this Mr Brown will appeal to the Queen's sentimental, though deeply-held, view that all Highlanders are good for the health.  If she can at least be persuaded to take the air, the prospect of further recovery may seem less remote... The assistant dresser pulls too tightly on her dress.  VICTORIA winces slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (terrified)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We glide slowly past the coastline as a caption reads:

dialogues.speaker: "ISLE OF WIGHT. 1864."
dialogues.text: A DRIVER stands against the sea front with a horse and ca bearing the Royal coat of arms. John BROWN leads his pony along the dockside, towards the waiting driver.  He is in his late thirties, fit, handsom and dressed in tartan kilt and short jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... He is arriving by boat this afternoon, by which time it is hoped Her Majesty will be in a fit state to consider riding out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIR HENRY PONSONBY, the Queen's Private Secretary, is sitting at his writing desk, completing a letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... As to that decision, along with all others, we remain, as ever, prisoners of the Queen's grief. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever your devoted husband, Henry. He folds the letter and slips it into an envelope.  He is middle-aged man in a dark mourning suit; tall, Saturnine and with a civil servant's stoop.  As he looks up, we see white-stockinged FOOTMAN standing to attention by the doo PONSONBY hands the letter to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Windsor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A series of windows are being slammed open by white stockinged FOOTMEN as members of the ROYAL FAMILY and UPP HOUSEHOLD hurry by in silence, all dressed in mourning an rushing to make the luncheon hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queen VICTORIA heads down the empty corridor with two ladies-in-waiting, LADY ELY and LADY CHURCHILL, hurrying along a pace behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Members of the Royal family and upper household hurry int the icy dining room and take their designated places at t luncheon table.  Everybody is dressed in mourning and nobody speaks.  Wind whistles through the open windows.  Silence. Among the diners we catch our first glimpse of BERTIE, th Prince of Wales.  He is in his mid-twenties, plump, stiff dressed and balding.  He stands next to his young wife, PRINCESS ALEXANDRA, who fiddles nervously with her shawl, trying to keep warm. As BERTIE smooths down his thinning hair, DOCTOR JENNER bustles into the dining room, stands himself next to PONSONBY and proceeds to conduct a hurried conversation with the Prince of Wales, entirely in whispers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Your Royal Highness!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A boy, I hear.  Excellent, excellent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Albert Victor.  Eddie for short.  What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fine choice, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN BROWN leads his pony gently up the ramp and into the carrier bearing the Royal coat of arms.  The DRIVER leans in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you riding up front? BROWN looks straight at this man, quiet and reserved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll stay with the pony, thank you.  She's all the way from Deeside and she's not sure she likes you yet. The DRIVER shrugs and slams the doors on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICTORIA reaches the dining room door and takes a deep breath.  LADY ELY and LADY CHURCHILL stop a pace behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many? LADY ELY is slightly taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Royal Family and senior members of the household, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. VICTORIA closes her eyes, then steels herself and steps through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone stiffens as VICTORIA walks in.  Acknowledging th other diners with a quick nod, the Queen takes her place. She flaps open her napkin and, bang on cue, everyone else sits and does the same.  The meal is served immediately b waiting SERVANTS, who plonk the food down without ceremon It's a very ordinary meal of meat and vegetables.  VICTOR starts eating heartily, straight away.  Everyone does the same. Only the clink of cutlery and the same eerie silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Royal horse-carrier rattles into the grounds and on down the driveway past the beautiful, manicured lawns stretching away towards the ornate twin towers of Osborne House.  A few outdoor servants watch its progress curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The silence continues as VICTORIA finishes her plain pudding.  Immediately, servants appear at every place and whip away the pudding bowls whether their owners have finished or not.  Nobody thinks this odd; it is part of t routine.  DOCTOR JENNER clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're expecting Brown this afternoon, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whom? A beat.  VICTORIA takes a sip of water, dabs her mouth wi her napkin and rises.  Everyone else rises too.  Suddenly the Queen turns to Bertie's nervous wife, PRINCESS ALEXANDRA, and proclaims abruptly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a very pretty shawl you are wearing, Alex.  Silk suits you well. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you are not eating enough.  One must not let vanity overrule one's appetite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. VICTORIA nods earnestly.  Lost to the effect her words ha had, she marches out again.  Behind her, she leaves PRINCESS ALEXANDRA feeling humiliated and crestfallen in front of all the others.  BERTIE takes her hand and squeezes tight, trying awkwardly to console.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horse-carrier pulls up outside the servant's entrance and the DRIVER opens the doors. JOHN BROWN pulls out a watch from his waistcoat and check the time.  His eyes narrow critically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was due at a quarter past one. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few minutes later, JOHN BROWN strides down the long corridor with PONSONBY at his side.  Their journey takes them down an endless series of corridors, past servants a householders hurrying about their duties.  The presence o the dead Albert is felt all around in the black-wreathed portraits and busts that crop up along the way. BROWN and PONSONBY could not be more contrasted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in low tones)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her Majesty's routine at Osborne House is not as you will remember it.  The Household remains in full mourning and no-one is permitted to raise their voice under any circumstances whatsoever.  As for the Queen's routine, she breakfasts at nine thirty, lunches at two,takes tea at five thirty and dinner at eight forty five.  No one is allowed to leave the building while the Queen is at home.  On the rare occasions when she is out, you may ask permission to leave, but only with my consent.  You're to be ready to walk the pony at any time after ten o'clock.  You'll clean her outdoor things and do any odd jobs as and when she requires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How will I know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised to be interrupted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How will I know what she requires?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be sent a message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'll bring it to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her Highness' Equerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need a man who knows where I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure it won't be difficult to find you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not good enough. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we'll have to see what can be arranged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, do. PONSONBY stiffens.  A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is to be no communication with other members of the household on matters concerning the court except through myself or one of the Equerries.  No plans must be altered unless you are given prior authority by myself or a senior member of the household.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came down at the Queen's request.  I'll take my orders from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In matters concerning the Household, I act on her behalf. BROWN takes the measure of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. BROWN glances up the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, is passing wind out of the question or do I need permission for that? PONSONBY refuses to acknowledge what he has heard.  They reach the door of the Royal Chamber and he concludes the interview.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I am sure you remember from Balmoral, you do not talk while in Her Majesty's presence unless Her Majesty addresses you directly. BROWN refuses to answer, so PONSONBY knocks.  After a moment, the door is opened by LADY ELY who ushers them in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BROWN walks stiffly into the room and stops.  PONSONBY waits by the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Brown, ma'am. VICTORIA is bent over the desk, working at one of her numerous red boxes.  She scribbles furiously at a letter, underlining and accenting words as she goes.  Finally, LA ELY steps up to her side and whispers something in her ea She carries on working. BROWN has time to survey the room.  Dominating everything are the same black-wreathed busts and portraits of Prince Albert glimpsed in the corridor. Finally, VICTORIA nods and LADY ELY beckons BROWN forward He steps up in front of the desk and waits.  VICTORIA loo up and BROWN bows deeply. Silence. She stares at him for a long moment without apparently registering who he is.  He towers over her, in bright tartan, while she sits hunched in her seat, all in black and knotted with tension. Finally, she finds her voice.  She sounds nervous and edg

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Brown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are here safely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the pony?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's well, too. VICTORIA blinks at the sight of him.  His presence is bringing him back.  A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your family sent cards.  It was much appreciated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad of it. In an effort to control her emotions, VICTORIA now sounds the same severe note as at lunch.  But BROWN, unlike others, seems unaffected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My husband was always very complimentary in speaking of you.  He would have approved, I am sure, of my calling on you in this way. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I trust it does not inconvenience you too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've no family, ma'am, apart from my brothers and sisters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a brother in service here, do you not? (furrowing her brow)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I forget his name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That will be company for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. Silence.  VICTORIA starts to tire.  She takes a sip of water and spills a little on herself.  Flustered, she searches for a hanky but cannot find one.  LADY ELY hurri up with one of her own and the Queen dabs it off.  BROWN watches all of this with genuine concern.  When VICTORIA finally looks up, he stares at her in deep sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honest to God, I never thought to see you in such a state.  You must miss him dreadfully. VICTORIA stares back in stunned silence.  PONSONBY coughs involuntarily.  LADY ELY freezes.  A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do not - he ... get him out. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him out.  Get him out! Suddenly, BROWN finds himself tugged backwards out of the room.  LADY ELY rushes up to assist as VICTORIA shouts herself into a fit of uncontrolled sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some minutes later, BROWN is angrily unpacking a trunk.  His humiliation expresses itself in the extraordinary ferocity with which he slams down every object. His younger brother, ARCHIE, sits on the bed.  He's in hi early thirties, bright, sharp and dressed in the same distinctive kilt and tweed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (telling it fast)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the day they arrive, she greets the Sultan and his family with barely a word and then retires to her chamber.  The Sultan, not used to State Occasions without a head of State, is standing in the lobby waiting for someone to tell him what to do.  But the court is under strict instructions not to talk in the corridors so nobody speaks to him, not a living soul, for the whole afternoon.  So now it's dinner and everyone's standing round the table -- still not a word -- waiting for Her Majesty to arrive.  One hour goes by, two, the Sultan's getting a wee bit peckish to say the least.  So finally, his wee laddy breaks for the cold meats and stuffs a slice in his mouth.  Well, the uproar when she heard.  You'd have thought someone had stolen the crown jewels. BROWN stares back, still pissed off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, there are rules.  Things you do and things you don't do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just telling the woman how I feel, for God's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't tell Her Majesty how you feel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I speak as I find, Archie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not down south you don't. BROWN slams a drawer shut.  ARCHIE lets it go and watches his brother.  A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what did Ponsonby do when she started shouting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he nearly ruptured his truss. A beat, then both men burst out laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clatter of voices and banging doors as under servants hurry about with plates, knives and forks, laying the Upp Servant's huge table for dinner.  ARCHIE leads BROWN through this rush of activity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventy a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad, not bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grinning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's pretty good for a ghillie. BROWN smiles dryly.  They pour themselves a drink from th table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prince Leopold?  Is he the one who bleeds all day?  So what does his valet do?  Wash his poultices for him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's better than shovelling horse shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you were looking for promotion, you should have picked one of the healthier ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's hardly a full hamper herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only grief makes her like she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three years, John.  Is that not a bit long to be grieving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She loved him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, man.  There's love and there's ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I do, Archie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's love and there's behaving like you do because there's nobody to tell you not to. Hold on BROWN.  He lets it go and moves on.  Across the hall, he spots the pretty ASSISTANT DRESSER watching them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one of us is she flirting with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The good-looking one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye?  Then she's obviously not got enough to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You work the system right, you could ask her yourself.  Just be thankful you're not working for Household.  The Queen never lets them out of her sight.  But wee spats like us can slip through the net, easy. A beat.  BROWN stares straight at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm no wee spat, ARCHIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next day, VICTORIA and her ladies are hurrying down a corridor on her way into the dining room.  VICTORIA suddenly stops and stares out of the windows.  Her entourage are several steps past her before they realize what's happened and scurry back to take up their position behind. Now we see what has caught her attention.  BROWN is standing in the courtyard below, by his pony.  She watche him for a moment, then without reacting, walks on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some hours later.  It is now raining. A gaggle of ROYAL GRANDCHILDREN hurry out of a carriage from their afternoon recreational while their NANNIES frantically try to keep them dry under the umbrellas.  Jo BROWN stands tall and erect on the gravel while they rush around him, laughing and giggling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain on the window.  VICTORIA is walking in the opposite direction down the corridor with her entourage.  She stop at the same place as before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if she had not seem him earlier)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is that? Lady Ely peers through the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Mr Brown, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is he doing there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He appears to be ... standing by his horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made no request to go out riding today. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long has he been there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, ma'am. (nervously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was observed earlier, I believe. At this moment, PONSONBY comes down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir Henry, Mr Brown is standing in the courtyard.  I have no wish to go riding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very sorry, ma'am.  I can't imagine -- he was certainly given no instructions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please make sure it does not happen again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, at once. VICTORIA takes one last look and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half an hour later, PONSONBY stands at his desk facing BROWN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What on earth did you think you were doing? BROWN stares straight back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awaiting my orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do not report for duty unless the Queen requests it.  You know that very well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't come all this way to sit on my arse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will await your orders like everyone else.  Unless you prefer a repeat of yesterday's little excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next day.  From a high window, we see PONSONBY scuttling madly across the courtyard towards the figure o JOHN BROWN, who is standing exactly as he was the day before. VICTORIA watches impassively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PONSONBY stands close to BROWN, shouting in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I made myself perfectly clear.  You do not leave your room until Her Majesty requests it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes straight ahead, shouting back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you tell Her Majesty from me, if her husband was here now, he'd have had her out of that house and getting some air in her.  What the hell's the point in me being here otherwise?! From the window above, VICTORIA takes in his words.  A beat.  PONSONBY collects himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go inside at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that the Queen's request?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it most certainly is! BROWN turns, grabs the lead rein and leads his horse back to the stables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few minutes later, BROWN is in the process of stabling his horse.  Suddenly he turns. VICTORIA is standing at the far end of the stable with he entourage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Brown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have been told repeatedly not to stand in the courtyard unless requested to do so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why do you persist in doing it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I think Her Majesty is wrong.  If ever there was a poor soul who needed fresh air, it is her. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen will ride out if and when she chooses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I intend to be there when she's ready. Silence.  The two of them stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next day, high and wide over the stunningly manicured landscape.  Long lawns, wind-cropped copses and in the distance, the glittering sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICTORIA sits side-saddle on a horse.  BROWN leads her in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICTORIA looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prince Albert was going to build a bench here.  He thought it one of the best views in Osborne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a fine spot, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thought so, yes. She stares ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In everything I do and everything I say, I try to think, as much as possible, what he would do, or say, if he were here now.  My Private Secretary wishes me to return to public duties-- She stops abruptly, but BROWN cuts in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Prince Albert were here today, he'd tell him a thing or two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir Henry is not alone.  They all wish it. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same people who refused to grant my husband the title of King because he was deemed of insufficient rank-- She stops again, cutting quickly back to small-talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a fine spot for a bench, is it not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have some letters in the saddle bag.  I wish to read them. BROWN walks up to her side, opens the saddle bag and hand her a bundle of letters held together with ribbon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot read them like that. BROWN undoes the ribbon and tries again.  VICTORIA cuts i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will hand them to me as I require. BROWN takes off the top letter and hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clatter and crush of the Upper Servant's table as UPP SERVANTS sit themselves down to dinner while UNDER SERVAN prepare to serve soup. ARCHIE comes in and sits himself somewhere in the middle next to an empty seat.  A moment later, BROWN strides in. But instead of sitting at the place beside his brother, h goes straight to the head of the table and plonks himself down.  Slowly, the clatter dies away as the whole room stops and stares at him in silence.  BROWN fixes them wit a look. An elderly butler steps into the room and stares in amazement at BROWN.  A smooth young man, BERTIE'S VALET, hurries up to intercede.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Carter, the Head Butler, sits there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not now he doesn't.  This is my place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By whose authority?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My own. A little frisson of oh-my-gawdness.  BERTIE'S VALET stare icily at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The order of seating at the Upper Servant's table is arranged personally by the Queen herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a tautology lad. (unable to stop himself seriously explaining it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you say the Queen arranges something, you've no need to say she's done it personally.  That's understood. But as far as BERTIE'S VALET is concerned, it isn't.  He stares down in mute fury, then snaps his fingers at one o the under servants, who rushes over.  There is a hurried exchange of whispers before the under servant rushes out. Unperturbed, BROWN brings out his flask and pours himself substantial draft of whiskey.  He turns to the pretty assistant dresser, sitting to his right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you dresser to Her Majesty? She blinks nervously at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Assistant, sir, yes. BROWN tucks into his soup.  Everyone watches and waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Taylor, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have I seen you up in Balmoral, Mary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope to go up next year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't happen to know what the Queen's reading for recreation, would you, Mary? The assistant dresser thinks for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord Tennyson, sir? BROWN nods.  All conversation stops as the under servant bursts back in.  She halts at the door, looking blankly from Bertie's valet to the elderly butler.  A beat.  The old man stiffens and makes his way to the middle of the table. BROWN looks up from his soup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I the only one eating? With a clatter of spoons, everyone obediently eats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few days later.  A morning "drawing room."  Standing round the unlit fireplace are DOCTOR JENNER, LADY ELY, LA CHURCHILL, the two LADIES IN WAITING and PRINCESS ALEXANDRA.  All are dressed against the icy wind that whistles through the open window where VICTORIA sits knitting busily while BERTIE stands beside her, coat buttoned up to the collar.  PONSONBY has stationed himsel opposite, beside a desk piled high with red dispatch boxe He runs through the daily itinerary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord Clarendon arrives, by invitation, at eleven o'clock, followed at twelve by a picnic in the grounds to celebrate Princess Alice's birthday.  Dispatches, as usual, at two. (finishes, then coughs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chancellor writes to say that, by happy coincidence, he will be in Cowes for the weekend.  He asks if Your Majesty might grant him an audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thought, perhaps, Your Majesty might wish to be informed of the latest developments in government.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I shall be out walking. A beat.  BERTIE watches closely now.  PONSONBY coughs again, nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then perhaps Your Majesty might consider it opportune if the Prince of Wales were to meet him on your behalf? VICTORIA stiffens.  She speaks without turning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On no account. PONSONBY gives up.  Politely, but firmly, BERTIE takes up the reins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama, I really do think it's time we made ourselves a little more ... available. VICTORIA carries on knitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we must accept our position in the country is not entirely unrelated to the continued absence of the Monarchy from public life. (silence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought perhaps we might consider a small gesture of some kind? VICTORIA looks up sharply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gesture?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought, a dinner for our ambassadors perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting in firmly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No dinners, Bertie. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you dressed for outdoors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so infernally cold in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cold is good-- (calling across)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that not so, Dr. Jenner?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cold is good!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent, ma'am, excellent. (trying his hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But perhaps if her Majesty were to consider accompanying her new-found physical vigor with the benefits of mental activity...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (becoming very agitated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why am I being lectured in this way?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, Your Majesty.  In no way did I wish to suggest--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting across him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not tolerate anybody lecturing me about the responsibility of the monarchy....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Least of all my son.  It was his irresponsibility that drove my husband to his grave. An appalled silence.  With great dignity, BERTIE absorbs the shock of the insult and quietly steers the conversati in another direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it is inconvenient to Her Majesty, then perhaps she might consider allowing the Prince of Wales to host--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do believe they send so many boxes to taunt me.  Doctor Jenner writes to them to say that my nerves are in an extremely fragile state and yet they continue to hound me with box after box after box after box after box! Silence.  VICTORIA has crossed to the window and stares o at the view.  Having recovered her composure, she turns t address them all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish to take the Princesses for a swim. For a moment, nobody believes what they have heard.  She continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The turns I have been taking in the grounds have proved most beneficial to me, and Brown thinks that salt water will do me good. Bertie stares at her in silence while PONSONBY and DOCTOR JENNER exchange a worried look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors of the Royal bathing-machine swing open and Que VICTORIA, in a voluminous swim-dress, sails out like a du into the freezing sea.  As she does so, the doors of the other machines open and Princess Helena and Princess Loui follow her in.  Dignity does not allow them to shout out, but their expressions of constipated agony are a picture. VICTORIA begins swimming around in a vigorous little circle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't potter, children.  Swim. Hold for a moment on the princesses' miserable faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half an hour later, PONSONBY, DOCTOR JENNER, LADY ELY and two FOOTMEN watch as BROWN helps VICTORIA up some steps a onto her horse.  He glances at the stiff line of householders and mutters curtly to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could buy that lot for garden ornaments and still see change from ten guineas. The household do not hear this, but QUEEN VICTORIA has overheard and tries to suppress a smile.  As she settles into the saddle, her foot comes loose.  BROWN fastens it into the stirrups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lift your foot, woman. Everyone hears this.  VICTORIA obeys.  Taking the reins, then walks the QUEEN out of the courtyard.  As they vanis from site, we hear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This nation is fortunate in so much as it is not governed by force...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The speech continues as we follow the progress of a Tomahawk cartoon doing the rounds of the Tory back benche from knee to knee.  It is entitled, "Where is Britannia?" and shows an empty throne draped with the Royal cloak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... but by a chain of traditions that have been cherished from generation to generation, because in them -- in our traditions -- are embodied all the laws which have enabled us to create the greatest empire of modern times... During the above, the cartoon reaches the front benches a lands on the knees of the young, earnest STANLEY.  As he frowns at the picture in front of him, DISRAELI winds up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... but, even though we have amassed great capital and even though we have established an industry with no parallel in the world, yet all these mighty creations are as nothing compared to the invisible customs that shape our lives.  To those honorable gentlemen of the opposition who seek to destroy the essential elements of this country, I say let them remember: England cannot begin again. During this peroration, we see DISRAELI for the first tim He is handsome, obviously Jewish and wire thin, like Dickens on Slimfast.  He dresses almost dandyishly but speaks with startling vigor; a combination of brilliance and cheek that is his key.  To cheers from his back benchers, he sits. As he looks up, he catches the eye of his opposite on the Liberal benches.  GLADSTONE is different in almost every respect; dour, dogged, heavy-set and tall.  They stare levelly for a second, then DISRAELI flashes a brilliant smile. STANLEY plops the cartoon on his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you seen this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few minutes later, DISRAELI and STANLEY are strolling down the busy lobby corridor.  Throughout their talk, Tor back-benchers bustle up to pat their hero on the back and offer their congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should we take it seriously?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cartoon or Her Majesty's absenteeism?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The question is, do we need her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surely, you're not suggesting we dispense--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear Stanley, a Prime Minister with only a handful of friends must respect public opinion. The pass GLADSTONE in a huddle of cohorts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gossip counts.  Lord Aberdeen was right.  This country is not governed by wisdom but by talk. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Granted, it wouldn't take much to winkle the old girl out of mourning, but if public opinion is against her, then it doesn't do to appear too close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see which way the wind blows. DISRAELI sweeps through a prattle of back-benchers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BROWN and ARCHIE crash into the water.  It is freezing.  BROWN braces himself against the icy shallows by bellowin Burns at the sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My heart's in the Highlands, my heart is not here!  My heart's in the Highlands a-chasing the deer!  Chasing the wild deer and following the roe!  My heart's in the Highlands wherever I go! ARCHIE is so creased up with laughing, he almost drowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few minutes later, BROWN and ARCHIE hurry back up the cold beach to rub themselves dry.  BROWN is very energize

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One box of biscuits, one box of drop tablets, one box of pralines, sixteen chocolate sponges.  It's the same order every week, but does anybody bother to check it?  Now she has to travel all the way to Balmoral without the few luxuries she actually enjoys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?  Someone'll send it on ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, but will they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, it's not your problem what she eats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman's surrounded by fools! (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has to be packed and ready to leave by seven thirty tomorrow morning.  Knowing that lot, they'll still be dressing her at eight. BROWN takes a nip of whiskey and offers some to his brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's got an army of people to get her up and out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm the only one she trusts. ARCHIE stares at him.  A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll blow hot and cold on you, John, she always does.  You want to be careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on ninety pounds a year plus seventy pounds for a pile of tartan I'd be wearing anyway.  That's as much as a Page of the Back Stairs gets and that job's only for toffs. (raising his hip flask triumphantly at the sea)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Her Majesty's Highland Servant!  Indoors and Out.  There's no stopping me now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few days later. The clatter of carriage and horse as the ROYAL PARTY thunders through gathering dark toward Balmoral Castle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mass of torches encircle the ROYAL PARTY as kilted GHILLIES and STAFF swarm round the carriage, opening door and clambering off boxes while a regiment of PIPERS play them in. Amid this swarm of activity, we glimpse BROWN opening the door to a smiling VICTORIA as she climbs down, followed b PRINCESS HELENA and PRINCESS LOUISE.  Emerging from anoth carriage come BERTIE and PRINCESS ALEXANDRA, staring grim faced at the castle.  HENRY PONSONBY and DOCTOR JENNER alight from their carriage as PONSONBY slips on his glove and pinches his nose at the pain of remembrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, not the pipes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next day. High over the vast, bleak mountains of Lochnager and Loch Muick.  VICTORIA and BROWN are riding fast towards the to Reaching the summit, VICTORIA points excitedly at the far horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are those?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those, over there, there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (horse chestnut trees...)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craobhan-geanmchno-fhiadhaich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craobhan-geanmchno... (bursts out laughing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I possibly say that with a straight face?! BROWN lets it go and they ride on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am thinking of publishing my "Highland Journals."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they worth reading?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am told so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who by?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir Henry Ponsonby tells me they are charming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does he know about the Highlands?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has been attending at Balmoral for many years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That doesn't make him an expert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His remarks were directed at the quality of the writing, not its subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't groom a horse to have it admired by others, I groom it because it needs grooming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curtly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not do it for others.  But Ponsonby thinks they are good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just say what you have to say, woman.  What other people think shouldn't matter to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snapping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I shall say what I have to say.  I always do. The stare at each other until BROWN kicks his horse on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, well, if all you want is a good opinion then he'd be sure to oblige you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (riding alongside)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What Mr Ponsonby was appreciating was their literary merit, a skill not intimately associated with the knowledge of grooming. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Literary appreciation does not begin and end with Tennyson. BROWN lowers his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a softer tone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mention you in them. BROWN says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In particular, the occasion when Albert was alive; the Royal Carriage overturned during a storm and you demonstrated such loyal service in returning the Queen and the Princesses safely to Balmoral. Taking a sprig of heather from her brooch, VICTORIA holds it out to him.  A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For friendship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few days later, PONSONBY, DOCTOR JENNER and BROWN stand at the chamber-desk, talking over the Queen's itinerary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (briskly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll be away on Friday between eight o'clock and six in the evening to visit the Grants in Glasalt.  If she's to make the journey there and back in the day she's to have no distractions the night before.  She'll take a light supper alone in her private drawing room and retire early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll need to sign dispatches before she retires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That can wait till the weekend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are important papers from --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can wait.  Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure Her Majesty is up to such a long journey?  She has only just recovered from a severe head cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I thought she wasn't up to it, I wouldn't let her go, would I? BROWN snaps together his papers and walks out, leaving PONSONBY and DOCTOR JENNER standing lamely at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next morning.  The ROYAL FAMILY are picnicking in the grounds.  VICTORIA walks along a path accompanied on one side by BROWN, on the other by BERTIE. BERTIE is in mid-plea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surely it is for the gentlemen to decide when to stop...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a disgusting habit, Bertie.  It should be discouraged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but isn't midnight a little excessive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is quite late enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But mama, the room was built expressly for that purpose.  It has been a smoking-room by tradition ever since father --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting in angrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brown's responsibilities are onerous enough already.  He has far too much to do without having to stay up all night waiting for you to go to bed.  The smoking-room will be closed and the lights put out at twelve o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that is my last word on the matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sorry, but I really do think it's too much that the gentlemen of the house should be dictated to by a servant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the Queen's decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon? (to VICTORIA)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama...? Before Bertie can continue, BROWN steps right into his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you should go now. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've tired your mother enough. BERTIE stares back, too stunned to speak.  He glances at his mother, but VICTORIA looks off into the distance as i she has not heard.  BERTIE turns and storms away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN BROWN is standing in the doorway of a small cottage watching, with amused detachment, as a middle-aged couple MR and MRS GRANT, race about their tiny living room, tryi desperately to make it presentable for the Queen's sudden visit.  They fling open the windows, slosh water on the fire, tidy up their two grubby BOYS, plump up the cushion dump knitting under the sofa and try to smarten themselve up, all in the space of a few seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's really no need for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll not have her seeing it like it is! (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know she means well, but I wish she'd warn us she was coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She thinks if she warned you, you'd go pouring water on the fire and stuffing the knitting under the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, well, you can't stop a wife being house-proud. MRS GRANT surveys the room critically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show her in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICTORIA sits on a horse and trap.  BROWN steps out and helps her down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're ready now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope they didn't go to any trouble, John.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICTORIA steps in to be greeted by all four GRANTS in one military row, smoke still steaming off the fire.  BROWN stands behind her, barely able to contain himself.  But f VICTORIA, it is all she's ever known and so she takes it perfectly normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Grant.  How good it is to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bowing deeply)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Grant.  How is your knee?  Has the pain eased a little?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bobbing in terror)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh not so bad, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  Oh and here are Douglas and John.  Haven't you grown?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still bobbing away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Growing all the time, ma'am. MR GRANT remembers himself and gestures VICTORIA towards chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you sit, ma'am? From his place by the wall, BROWN notices how easily she smiles as she is led to the chair.  She points to a pictu on the wall and her good humour is infectious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that!  That's Cairn Lochan.  We picnicked there once, did we not, John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few days later, a party of ARISTOCRATS, MINISTERS, DIPLOMATS, ESCORTS, BUSINESSMAN and WHORES.  Into this brouhaha come DISRAELI, his elderly wife MARY ANNE and th young STANLEY.  It is all eyes and nods here.  Everyone knows everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, the greasy pole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be facetious, dear. Remember your position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my position I'm thinking of. Across the room, STANLEY spots BERTIE amid a crowd of acolytes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see the Prince of Wales is here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope he got his mother's permission. STANLEY smiles faintly.  DISRAELI homes in on a punter an raises his hand, already working the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord Salisbury!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The society party is hotting up.  STANLEY is deep in conversation with three SOCIETY LADIES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ridiculously pleased with herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is the Queen penny-wise and pound foolish?  Because she looks after the Browns and lets the sovereigns take care of themselves! A peal of naughty laughter.  Unseen, DISRAELI steps up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And in your opinion?  Is she foolish? The SOCIETY LADY stares blankly back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I ... well, I mean to say, it's hardly right, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, the Queen and -- (appalled whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Brown. DISRAELI stares at her steadily, already thinking ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: La superstition met le monde entier en flammes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thick as shit)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (changing tack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has anybody seen this ... Mr Brown?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is her personal servant, I believe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (knowingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follows her wherever she goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He would hardly make a very good personal assistant if he did not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BROWN stands by a wall, smiling to himself at the sight o QUEEN VICTORIA struggling to help lay the table while MRS GRANT nervously prattles on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... it's not my best china.  I mean, it is my best china now, but the family set got stolen last summer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm so sorry ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it was no-one on the Estate.  More likely one of the lads from Braemar.  Or further even. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll fetch the salt. MRS GRANT scurries away.  VICTORIA immediately holds up t spoons to BROWN with a questioning look -- above or besid the plate?  He nods her to the top and she quickly carrie on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DISRAELI and MARY ANNE stand with BERTIE and his ACOLYTES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Disraeli.  Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Royal Highness.  What a pleasure to see you here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you met Mr Lyle?  He's in sugar...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I've had that pleasure. DISRAELI shakes hands with the fat sugar tycoon who wobbl with drink.  MARY ANNE engages him in conversation while BERTIE turns DISRAELI aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No doubt you've heard the rumors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take no account of gossip, Your Highness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My concern is for the reputation of the Monarchy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fear the influence he has on her.  The man's word is not to be credited.  He is an arriviste of the very lowest water. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's having a bust cast of him.  In Nero Marquino marble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would talk to her myself, but she won't listen to me.  She must be persuaded, by someone she respects, to abandon this ridiculous favoritism before a situation develops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A situation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't imagine you frequent the Republican Clubs.  But the fact that neither you nor I are members should not blind us to the significance of their existence. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Tory Party has always been our party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm flattered you think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you, if we don't stick together on this, you could find yourself First President's Opposition. (murdering it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Du Royaum Uni.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think we can overstate the seriousness of this. DISRAELI nods and BERTIE walks swiftly back to his party. The moment he's gone, STANLEY steps up to DISRAELI's side

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To know when he'll be king.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICTORIA, BROWN and the GRANTS are eating around a large table.  Like a wife watching her husband, VICTORIA beams proudly at BROWN as he tells a story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... so Grant here and myself are riding over Lochnagar and the rain's pouring down in sheets and all we're thinking about is getting home for a drink, when through the gloom Grant spots a couple of poachers.  He gives me a shout and we chase them down towards the loch until Grant has your men up against the stacks and he's shouting and cursing at them, "Why are you poaching on Royal land?!"  And one of the little fellas looks up at him and says, "coz we've come up in the world." For a split second, both the GRANTS look petrified, then BROWN and VICTORIA explode into laughter and the GRANTS relax.  Suddenly the GRANTS are helpless with laughter to Beginning with VICTORIA's glass, BROWN pours out liberal quantities of whiskey all round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later that night, the courtyard is packed with a gaggle o worried HOUSEHOLDERS holding lamps. Through the light, BROWN and VICTORIA clatter into the courtyard on the horse and trap.  DOCTOR JENNER breaks through the crowd in a state of high excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Majesty!  Thank goodness you're safe!  I'll have a bath prepared immediately.  I recommend Macdonald's African Embrocation --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, pipe down, man.  The woman's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We stayed a little longer than expected with Mr and Mrs Grant.  It was most agreeable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were expecting you to return by six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now I am back. BROWN cannot resist one more little dig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We took a nip of whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To keep out the cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye. VICTORIA smiles and BROWN lifts her off the trap.  Before walking in she turns and, in front of everyone, says...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, John. BROWN bows and the QUEEN walks on.  As she straightens up he finds PONSONBY and DOCTOR JENNER staring back at him i utter disbelief at what she has just said.  He turns and leads the horse back to the stables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's drunk. PONSONBY doesn't answer.  He is watching BROWN very closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A distinct flushing around the cheeks.  She was drunk, I tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, she wasn't. Silence.  JENNER turns to look at PONSONBY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surely not ... PONSONBY's face is set hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't even think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crush of kilted GHILLIES as we slam into the height of the annual Ghillie's Ball. The whole court is reeling through the dance; all of them beholding the extraordinary spectacle of QUEEN VICTORIA a JOHN BROWN dancing together in the middle of the hall. PONSONBY and JENNER stand by the wall, watching.  Close-u on PONSONBY'S face as JENNER mutters darkly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pandora's Box ... With a slam of feet the reel ends, the GHILLIES roar and BROWN and VICTORIA stand smiling at each other in silence A King and his Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later that night. We find BROWN, slouched on the ground, dead-drunk and snoring loudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few days later, four JOURNALISTS are scrabbling up a stony path, armed with telescopes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large ROYAL PARTY is making its way smoothly and quietl up the mountain.  BROWN is on horseback, leading VICTORIA on a dapple-grey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The JOURNALISTS rattle up the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BROWN and VICTORIA start pulling ahead of the main party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The JOURNALISTS scramble up to some gorse bushes, dump themselves down and start setting up the telescopes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BROWN and VICTORIA near the summit when BROWN suddenly stops.  He stiffens and turns to face the wind, as if catching a scent.  VICTORIA frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, John? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard something. BROWN's eyes fix on some distant gorse bushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't be long. He dismounts and races off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The JOURNALISTS are peering through their telescopes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did he get to?  I've lost him? Below them, BROWN races across the riverbank and undergrowth, unseen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if there's much worth writing about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard to tell. BROWN rears up above them and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This close enough for you?  Go on!  On your way!  You filthy scavengers! The JOURNALISTS scramble to their feet and start legging down the hill, while BROWN roars furiously, hurling their bags after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You leave her alone, do you hear?! The JOURNALISTS vanish below the hillside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That night. BROWN is standing at the head of the table, yelling at th UPPER SERVANTS, irrespective of ARCHIE or anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I catch the miserable by-blow who told those men where she'd be, then I'll hang his balls to dry on Jock Wemyss, so I will!! ARCHIE glances up at BERTIE'S VALET.  He is staring down the table, teeth gritted, fists clenched.  BROWN rounds o them all again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happens to John Brown is his business, but the Queen's security will never be compromised!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll talk when I'm finished! BERTIE'S VALET stares at him in astonishment.  BROWN turn back to the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That kind of disloyalty will not be tolerated in this house, is that clear? (beat, yelling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, is that clear?! There is a general mutter of assent.  BROWN turns and storms out as ARCHIE gets up to follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few days later, PONSONBY is sitting at his desk, hands his hips, listening quietly as DOCTOR JENNER reads from h copy of Punch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Court Circular, Balmoral." (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "On Tuesday, Mr John Brown enjoyed a display of sheep-dipping by local farmers.  On Wednesday, he attended a seance where he was pleased to listen to a recital of Auld Lang Syne by Mr Robert Burns himself ..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BROWN crashes through a door holding a copy of the same journal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... On Thursday, Mr John Brown walked on the slopes, accompanied by family and friend ..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BROWN storms up to PONSONBY's door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Brown retired early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BROWN bursts in on PONSONBY and JENNER, slamming down his copy of Punch on the desk.  He is furious but controlled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I find out that you had anything to do with this, I will have you sacked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe that decision rests with Her Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't think I can't persuade her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't doubt that the Queen was highly amused.  She has always had a very healthy sense of humor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a slur on her good name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In as much as the article is about yourself, I think you must now accept that the public has a right to its interest in you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody has any rights over me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are all of us subject to forces beyond our control, Mr Brown, even you. BROWN stares at him in silence.  A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll regret saying that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaos.  The Tories are losing the vote as both sides of t house stand and shout at each other while the SPEAKER ris in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Order!  Order!  ORDER! A buzzing silence settles as the house sits for the vote. The COUNTERS approach the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Result of the vote to the first reading of the Bill to Disestablish the Irish Church. A murmur of excitement from the LIBERALS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Order! A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ayes to the right, three hundred and thirty, noes to the left, two hundred and sixty-five... By the time he reaches "sixty-five" his voice is drowned cheers from the Liberal benches.  DISRAELI and the rest o the front bench sit in stony silence. Somewhere on the Liberal back benches, a wild-eyed maverick, DILKE, rises to his feet shouting:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Speaker, I table a motion in furtherance of the Bill to Disestablish the Monarchy! A roar from the irate TORIES and chaos reigns again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Order!  Order!!  ORDER!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An hour later the house is empty except for a few straggling MPs hurrying home.  An exhausted DISRAELI stan in the corridor with STANLEY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't know that for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gladstone's got his party facing the same way for the first time in years.  We need help. (long beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is the old girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs Brown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's questionable whether there's any advantage to be had from that direction.  She's never been less popular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the press, perhaps. (holding up Punch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she's sold more copies of her Highland Journal in three months than Punch will ever sell in a year.  Time to wheel her out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's refusing to leave Balmoral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's her excuse this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Princess Louisa is too ill to move.  Frankly, the Queen's rather upset at the recent spate of bad publicity. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was trying to imagine "rather upset." The elderly prelate, DEAN WELLSELLY, hurries in through t lobby doors.  DISRAELI puts on a welcoming smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, gentlemen.  I'm late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all, Dean.  Good of you to spare the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came as quickly as I could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've seen the latest cartoon in Punch, I take it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (completely lost)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon? DISRAELI opens the copy of Punch and hands it to Dean Wellselly.  The Dean clears his throat and starts to read

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Wellselly reads)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of our madder brethren in the house was calling for disestablishment of the monarchy. Dean Wellselly looks up from the article, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good Lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playing the soft glove)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure it won't come to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the hard glove)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  But it has now become a matter for our consciences. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just telling Stanley how vital it is that the nation should feel the visible influence of the Sovereign.  As a reminder that Parliament, indeed my own ministry, depends on the will of the Queen. DEAN WELLSELLY nods his head gravely.  Over his shoulder, STANLEY is gaping at DISRAELI's silky distortion of the party political maneuver into a moral imperative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't agree with you more, but I am only Dean of Windsor.  I don't understand what ... DISRAELI interrupts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear from Balmoral that Mr Brown is interesting Her Majesty in some of the forms of worship associated with ... low-church Presbyterian. Silence.  DEAN WELLSELLY'S face is a picture of unrestrained horror.  Low-church.  Presbyterian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, several things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some days later. Queen VICTORIA sits at her desk while Henry PONSONBY stan in front of her, holding a copy of The Times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read it! PONSONBY coughs once and begins again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The Times wishes to join the rest of Her Majesty's loyal subjects in expressing its deep joy at the news that the Queen is soon to come out of her mourning." VICTORIA glowers at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who told them that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I -- forgive me, ma'am, I am no wiser than yourself. Suddenly, VICTORIA's temper goes and she shouts at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No-one should think themselves wiser than me! (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not for any of the Queen's subjects to presume to tell Her Majesty when and where She should come out of mourning.  It is the Queen's sorrow that keeps her secluded!  It is Her overwhelming amount of work and responsibility, work which She feels will soon wear her out entirely!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Majesty --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting right through him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it not enough that She is uncheered and unguided that she should also have to suffer these malicious rumors?! (a pause, more quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not a fool. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know there are those in the establishment too afraid to attack me and so they attack my dearest friends.  Sometimes -- I feel that Brown is all I have left of Albert. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now they attack Brown too. She looks up, eyes blazing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not give him up to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BROWN is guarding the door to the drawing room while the balding BERTIE muscles up, eye ball to eye ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish to see my mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Convey her a message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's away to Windsor tomorrow.  Talk to her there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her the Prince of Wales wishes to speak with her urgently about matters concerning the press.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you deaf as well as stupid? A split-second.  BERTIE gapes at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, are you deaf as well as stupid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know who you address, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whom you address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The future King! A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, everyone's entitled to their opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of my way! Foolishly, BERTIE tries to barge his way past.  Suddenly BROWN loses it completely.  He grabs the Prince of Wales the shoulders and pins him back, shouting right into his face.

dialogues.speaker: LEAVE US ALONE, WHY DON'T YOU
dialogues.text: For a split-second, BROWN's eyes flicker as he senses he has gone too far.  A look of pure venom in BERTIE'S face, then ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weeks later. In a roar of hooves and wheels, the Royal Carriage sweeps into the huge quadrangle.  JOHN BROWN stands rigid on the box, glowering at all the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pair of doors open out onto a torchlit driveway as a ma of SERVANTS rush in and out, ferrying bags an trunks. BROWN marches in, still charged-up from the strain of the journey's watchfulness.  He spots an UNDER-PORTER snatchi a break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You!  What's your business here?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jumping to)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under-porter, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, don't stand where you shouldn't! The UNDER-PORTER scrambles up the stairs.  A few SERVANTS exchange looks.  BROWN seems more determined than ever to exert his control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That night. Carrying an old storm lamp high over his head, BROWN walk towards the stables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next day. BROWN is on horseback, riding with VICTORIA through the grounds.  He is still jumpy, eyes flicking left and right searching for intruders.  They are being followed at a distance by two EQUERRIES on horseback.  VICTORIA frowns peevishly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must they always follow us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ordered it.  It's for your own safety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear me, you'll be telling me to watch what I eat next. BROWN doesn't react.  A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I not safe enough with you, John?
