dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye. (looking away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there are Fenians reported on the mainland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tutting irritably)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The threat from the Irish is greatly exaggerated, I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snapping back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll decide when it's exaggerated. BROWN chucks his horse on, bringing a firm halt to the conversation.  A beat.  He pulls up suddenly, staring at the shadows in the copse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is anything the matter, John? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John? He stares for along moment and then lets it go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing's the matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BROWN marches down the line of horse boxes.  A stable-lad BARNEY, is feeding the horses.  He looks twitchy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Barney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Brown, sir --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's cold out there tonight, Barney. Reaching his pony, BROWN stops and smiles.  The animal lifts its face to him and he softly strokes his muzzle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, there's a good girl. (to Barney)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you had a look at this hoof?  She was limping badly.  I think there might be a stone in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah, I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good man.  And is she all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  She's a good girl.  Aren't you?  Yeah, she's a lovely girl.  And you know the Queen's riding tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right, Barney? BARNEY twitches again and BROWN realizes too late.  The split-second he turns, he sees THREE MEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, aye... The MEN pile onto him and he collapses under their weight As he falls, BROWN manages to yank himself round, bang up fist and fling the others off him.  But the FIRST MAN is again, twisting an arm round his neck and tugging him bac The others grapple his arms down, but BROWN is incredibly strong.  Even now, grunting and scrabbling, he makes them fight to force him back.  BARNEY stands transfixed in horror. Dumping BROWN against the wall, the men step back and sta kicking the shit out of him.  BROWN curls into a ball, ja locked, hands over his head.  Not a sound. Finally, they back off, panting hard.  The FIRST MAN pull out a bottle of whiskey, yanks back BROWN's head and forc whiskey down his throat.  It spills over his face and dribbles down his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next day. VICTORIA is standing at the windows.  The door opens and LADY ELY walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Brown is unable to attend today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe he is unwell, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unwell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand he was in a fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has he been hurt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe not, ma'am.  I understand -- he'd had rather too much to drink. VICTORIA walks away and steps behind her desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may go. LADY ELY bows and walks out.  VICTORIA stares at the desk moment, then picks up her pen and tries to work.  She cannot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BROWN sits on the edge of the bed in only his undergarments.  His face, arms, legs and fingers are livi with bruises, but he sits there, stiff-backed and grittin his teeth, while ARCHIE crouches in front of him, tending to his wounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she sent no word down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They said you were drunk. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you tell her the truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll think it's her fault for keeping me. ARCHIE completes one of the dressings when BROWN suddenly reaches back and starts trying to put on his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got three broken ribs, man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got my duties to attend to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be an idiot!  You're in no fit state to go anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll be worried about me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll get over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't let her down now, Archie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when was the last time she put herself out for you?  Look, John, whatever she says to you now, in the end you're still a servant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm much more than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, she may say that to you, but the woman can say what she wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You watch your tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, man, I'm telling you what you already know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know nothing about her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When are you gonna see it, John?  She doesn't give a damn about you. BROWN lunges for the bedside drawer and pulls out a card showing a coy picture of a pretty woman.  He holds it up, eyes blazing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the Queen! He reads out the inscription.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lips may give a message better of Christmas love than e'en this letter. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To my best friend, J.B. from his best friend, V.R. (he thrusts it in his brother's face)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best friend!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She means it. ARCHIE stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll drop you.  When she's done with you, she'll drop you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out! ARCHIE steps back but BROWN roars at him.

dialogues.speaker: OUT
dialogues.text: ARCHIE steps outside and BROWN is left alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next day.  VICTORIA sits at her desk.  PONSONBY hands her letters to sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... to be followed by a visit from Lady Bridport.  She is keen to secure a place for her niece as Maid of Honor. VICTORIA signs the last letter and sits back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am tired. PONSONBY coughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is one other matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a letter, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From whom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Princess Helena and other members of your family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stiffening defensively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My family is quite capable of communicating with the Queen in person. PONSONBY does not reply.  Finally, VICTORIA is obliged to ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do they want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are demanding the dismissal of John Brown on grounds of drunkeness. VICTORIA stares through the window, expressionless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICTORIA walks through the ornate chapel, nervously fingering her handkerchief.  Waiting for her, smiling softly, is the Dean of Windsor, DEAN WELLSELLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wished to see me, ma'am? She holds his eyes for a moment, then nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few minutes later, VICTORIA and DEAN WELLSELLY are seat in a corner of the chapel, talking softly.  She cannot bring herself to look at him and so does not notice how carefully he is watching her throughout the interview.  This is incredibly hard for her to say, but she struggles to be as honest as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My husband tried always to make me think more subtly.  Of course he taught me so much and I can never repay my debt to him, or the love I feel, even now.  But, in truth, I think I am someone who can only feel things while they are alive to me.  For that reason, I know I do not have a subtle mind.  I know that.  But I work hard and I try to do my duty. (she hesitates; she is struggling now)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: However, I have noticed of late that my feelings of grief are not so strong and -- that I find myself leaning more upon the comfort of living friends. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friends close to me now. She stops herself.  She is crying.  DEAN WELLSELLY watche her a moment, then speaks close, choosing his words carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Majesty, a settled resignation is more lasting proof of affection than active grief.  If the good Lord sees fit to bring one into contact with congenial fellow beings, one should not analyze one's reaction too deeply.  To allow oneself to be comforted by someone else need not imply any disloyalty to the memory of the loved one. Silence.  VICTORIA stares into the long, dark chapel.  Gradually, as she takes in the tone of his remarks, her disappointment turns to anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next day, VICTORIA stands at the far window and her back to the room.  Lined up against the wall are BERTIE a his siblings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir Henry. PONSONBY steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please tell the Princess, and other signatories to this letter, that the Queen will not be dictated to, or made to alter, in any way, what she has found to answer for her comfort. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I make myself clear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may go. They all file out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few days later. BROWN and VICTORIA are riding on horseback.  Although better than he was, BROWN'S face is still badly bruised.  They turn a corner banked by trees.  BROWN is watching th QUEEN closely.  She stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would like to get down. Without a word, BROWN dismounts and helps her off her horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was told you were in a fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has someone seen to those bruises?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having considered my position here at court, I have come to the conclusion that it is in the best interest of Your Majesty that I should resign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do not accept. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had foreseen that you would not.  But Your Majesty should understand -- that my mind will not be changed in this.  I leave for Deeside --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen forbids it. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot allow it because I cannot live without you.  Without you, I cannot find the strength to be who I must be.  Please. She takes his hand to her mouth and kisses it gently, the looks at him, utterly helpless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Promise me you won't let them send me back. A long silence.  BROWN holds her hand tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few weeks later. A tiny horse-drawn carriage creeps across a huge Highland landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday, Gladstone talked for three hours on the Irish Church Bill ... I am as guilty as the rest of underestimating his reforming zeal. Tory days may be numbered, but I fancy there yet remains one last hope of deliverance.  Wheresoever the blame lies, we must now close ranks and defend Mrs Brown's England.  As for my interminable journey to the land of Calvin, oatcakes and sulphur ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DISRAELI hurries through the pouring rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... no Prime Minister made greater sacrifice than attempting to run the country six hundred miles north of civilization. Reaching the castle, he hurries inside and the great door bang behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next day. QUEEN VICTORIA is playing the piano like she walks, with great vim and vigor.  The tune is some quaint Scottish ballad which she belts out in her clear strong voice, almost drowning out PRINCE ARTHUR, PRINCE LOUISE and PRIN LEOPOLD who are meant to be accompanying her.  They stand in a nervous semi-circle, fumbling their harmonies.  Ignoring them completely, VICTORIA bobs up her head with quizzical smile to make sure she is being appreciated. DISRAELI and the rest of the HOUSEHOLD stand a few yards off, smiling rigidly.  DISRAELI, the consummate politicia to his inch-high insteps, out-smiles the lot of them.  Th man is in raptures of delight.  And the more liquid his smiles, the happier he makes VICTORIA.  He beams, she belts, until her children are drowned out completely. And then, with characteristic suddenness, VICTORIA stops playing and launches into one of her tirades.  The HOUSEHOLD wobbles in shock like children on a switch-back but DISRAELI glides smoothly from delight to sober concer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How dare the Irish break with the Anglicans?  If Albert were alive today he would never allow the Crown to give up Church patronage.  No, the Irish must be told, very firmly, to stay exactly where they are.  It is the thin edge of the wedge, Mr Disraeli.  Next, you will be telling me that the Crown no longer governs this nation. A beat. A nervous silence in the Household.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Majesty remains at the very epicenter of governance.  As for your people, look no further than the sales of your Highland Journals to see in what affection the nation holds their Queen. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sell even more copies than Mr Dickens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I lack your prose, Mr Disraeli. VICTORIA gives him a tiny smile.  DISRAELI acknowledges i then steers the conversation back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I understand your concern.  You miss your people. (a pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they miss you. VICTORIA registers a slight flicker of defensiveness at t implied criticism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then they may read about me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed, and for that they are eternally grateful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that not enough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In so many ways ... and yet it is your presence they crave.  A figurehead. VICTORIA has the measure of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never thought to be bullied by you, Mr Disraeli.  You, I thought, understood a widow's grief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, ma'am, I cannot speak for the nation, only for myself.  As Prime Minister I confess I miss your presence, but that is only an expression of my own selfish desires and I should not burden you with it. The Household waits.  Has he clawed himself back?  VICTOR acknowledges his apology.  Her voice drops and she talks directly to DISRAELI, straight from the heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stay here because I am happy. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that such a terrible crime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, ma'am. At this moment the far door opens and BROWN walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time for your walk. Without a word, VICTORIA rises from her chair and starts following him out.  As they pass DISRAELI, she stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my good John Brown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking him in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have asked him to show you a little of Highland life while you are with us at Balmoral. BROWN measures DISRAELI suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What brings you here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man can refuse only so many invitations from his Queen.  It was remiss of me not to come earlier. VICTORIA smiles.  BROWN stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you know about the Highlands?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am a blank sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you hunt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Occasionally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dare say you can be taught.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To shoot perhaps, but not to kill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you hunt, you kill. DISRAELI counters effortlessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then, I'll do my best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staying close to the ground we develop through a series o shots showing the other highlands -- sheet rain against heather and gorse, rivulets of water slashing through mud crude pathways sliding in wind and all ball-breakingly cold. Coming up the hill, we begin to make out a hunting party. The sound first.  Like a small army, crashing their way u the winding path.  GHILLIES urging on their horses and dogs, guns and equipment jangling off pony-hacks an then the tall figure of JOHN BROWN striding out in front. Making no concession to anyone, he force-marches them up the hill, eyes on the hunt ahead. Behind them trot the me on horseback -- DISRAELI, PONSONBY, BERTIE and other GENTLEMEN, each led by GHILLIES and ATTENDANTS, among the ARCHIE. Suddenly, BROWN stops and raises a hand.  The party halts He listens for a second.  Satisfied that he has found his quarry, he brings his hand down and the party of gentleme dismount as quietly as they can. As he waits, BROWN winces slightly from the pain in his side.  He pulls a flask of whiskey from his sporran and drinks.  All the time, DISRAELI keeps his eyes on BROWN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stalking. Everyone is now fanned out along the hillside, a ghillie each gentleman, slowly and silently moving up the hill. DISRAELI stalks with BROWN, panting hard to keep up, eyes on his man, trying to make no sound. Suddenly, BROWN stops.  Very slowly he rises.  DISRAELI rides alongside and sees ... A huge stag staring majestically across the hillside. Keeping his movements smooth and slow, BROWN brings up hi rifle, cocks it and offers DISRAELI the kill.  With a deferential gesture of the hands, DISRAELI declines.  BRO stares at him a split-second, raises the rifle to his shoulder and fires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kill. A rapid montage of guns firing, as we cut to ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BROWN sweeps in from the hunt, DISRAELI dripping at his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (demonstrating with his rifle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always remember, you keep it tight to your shoulder, you absorb the kick.  Aim for the head.  Then imagine it's Gladstone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite. BROWN pulls out his flask and offers some to DISRAELI, wh declines.  He watches BROWN take a long swig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That night. BROWN is standing at his place, drinking steadily.  He ha a sheet of paper and a pen and is ticking off a list.  Lined up in front of him, trying desperately not to laugh are five or six UPPER SERVANTS including the pretty ASSISTANT DRESSER and BERTIE'S VALET.  They each step up, one at a time, to make their report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ticking as he goes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Back doors, West Wing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Checked and locked, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Side doors, East Wing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Checked and locked, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louder, girl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (creasing up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Checked and locked, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kitchen and lower house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Checked and locked, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back and upper corridors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Checked and locked, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Front door. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Checked and locked. Folding up the paper, BROWN downs his glass of whiskey an sits.  On his nod, dinner is served by UNDER SERVANTS ami a clatter of cutlery and chat. ARCHIE looks across at his brother but BROWN is hunched over his plate, pecking at his food. Someone titters and ARCHIE looks up.  BERTIE'S VALET coughs.  BROWN slowly lifts his head.  His eyes have the slightly unfocused look of too much drink.  It is clear t ARCHIE that he is about to be sent-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a smug smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see any Irish assassins today, Mr Brown? Brown doesn't react.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We heard the dogs were Fenian sympathizers. Brown drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or was it the stag ...? Everyone bursts out laughing.  Brown slams down his glass

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's not a soul here cares about that wee woman's safety except me!  She'd die in a ditch if I wasn't there to look out for her -- He stops.  ARCHIE has come across to his brother's chair and pulls gently on his arm. BROWN stares at the SERVANTS.  Everyone is about to burst out laughing.  Keeping his dignity, he pushes back his chair and lets ARCHIE lead him away. As BROWN reaches the double doors, the laughter hits him the back like a wave. ARCHIE holds him steady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BROWN is lying on a grubby bed.  ARCHIE is looking around the untidy room.  For the first time, he notices a thick manuscript on the table.  BROWN follows his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a diary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful who sees it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you take me for? ARCHIE turns back to BROWN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should have someone look after you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all right.  I just need to rest up a wee bit. (feeling everything spin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room ... You don't have to stay. BROWN shuts his eyes and starts to drift.  ARCHIE watches over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is a mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't move to tidy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's what the maids are for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not having some prattler going through my things. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't you give yourself a rest, John?  She's other people to look out for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She needs me, Archie.  She canna do without me, she said it to my face. (his hands come up to cover his eyes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I stop now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn the next morning. BROWN is scrambling into his jacket as he hurries down th stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BROWN crashes out of a side-door -- just fully dressed -- to be met by the smiling figure of DISRAELI.  He is got u in smart walking boots, plus-fours and a tweed jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sent for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been called back to London.  My last day.  I thought I might take a walk on Lochnagar. BROWN stares straight back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An hour later, BROWN leads DISRAELI up the hill.  BROWN h his head down, on with the job.  DISRAELI slows to a halt

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Princes and Lords are but the breath of kings, An honest man's the noblest work of God. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must miss such magnificent views.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think about it. They reach the top and continue along the high ground.  DISRAELI glances at BROWN and notices the limp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, I've called you out and you should have been resting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're injured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still, someone must attend you.  Your wife should not have let you out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadpan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the top. DISRAELI admires the view for a moment, then continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I confess, I sometimes feel as if I am not married myself, I see my wife so little.  But I'm forgetting the rewards. He looks across.  BROWN keeps staring ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The look on their faces when one walks into the room.  Still gives one a ridiculous thrill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surely --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I do, I do for my Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was there never ambition?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe, once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I envy yo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To have achieved one's ambition, or to have reconciled oneself to its limits, is a lifetime's work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do what I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Her Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But yourself? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about John Brown?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I serve the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No other aspiration? BROWN stares for a long moment.  Finally he speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To see her safe. DISRAELI steps a little closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will not be unaware of the threat now posed by Republicanism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you think I keep her here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, but therein lies the paradox.  It is her very isolation that encourages the malcontents.  The longer she is away, the stronger they become; and who, honestly, can promise security against that?  However many doors you lock, someone will always get in.  Even here. BROWN watches him, eyes alert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth is, the Queen would be safer doing her duty and returning south to her public.  John Bull loves her and John Bull is her best defense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her mind is set.  She won't change now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She trusts you, John. DISRAELI is right on his shoulder now, like his own voice

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The threat. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell them, but they don't see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They aren't as watchful as you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too busy looking after themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The greasy pole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No loyalty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No love. Silence.  For a moment BROWN seems unaware that someone else has said that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promised to protect her from people like you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For once in my life, I am not the issue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll never understand it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In time, she will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll think I betrayed her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But others will know that you acted for the greater good. BROWN stares off into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next day. BROWN is rowing VICTORIA across the loch.  The EQUERRIES wait on the shore. VICTORIA trails her hand in the water, frowning at the surface.  BROWN concentrates on the oars, slipping them carefully through the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I received a letter today from Mr Disraeli.  Parliament is calling for my return to public duties. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why won't they let us be? BROWN does not answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He insists that the country expects me to preside over the opening of the new session.  I refuse to offer sustenance to enable his weakening grip.  Besides, you know how much I should hate it.  It frightens me. She notices that BROWN has said nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John? BROWN does not look at her.  Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't always have what we wish. VICTORIA stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later that day. VICTORIA and BROWN are in the middle of a blazing row in front of the entire Household, including PONSONBY, JENNER and LADY ELY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duty?!  You talk about duty?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If duty and safety are served by the same end then, aye, I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cannot believe you are saying this?  You, who I have relied on all this time --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have I ever let you down before--?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if he had not spoken)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- You stand there and tell me it is my duty ... after all you promised me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm breaking no promises!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are forcing me to do the very thing you know I fear most!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For god's sake, woman, I'm just trying to keep you safe!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not hear any more about my safety!!  You made me a promise and now you have broken it! BROWN rounds on her, deeply wounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- When I took you out riding, come rain or shine, because I knew it was right for you, when I kept the bairns off your back so you could have a bit of peace, when I saw you safe from home to home and you didn't even know I was there...!  All I've ever thought about is you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why send me back to them?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I have to! (pause

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you no listen to me, woman? Face turned from him, VICTORIA replies in a brittle voice

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do not presume to talk to your Queen in that manner. A long silence.  BROWN watches her, but she will not look at him again.  Finally, she walks very slowly across the room.  She turns in the doorway, her voice faltering slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Jenner, I feel unwell.  I shall retire to my chamber.  Please attend me presently. As the door slams, we ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few weeks later. Close on a door as it opens.  The ROYAL FAMILY are eating lunch with members of the UPPER HOUSEHOLD.  VICTORIA walk in with LADY ELY. A great scraping of chairs as everyone drops their forks and stands.  Clearly, they were not expecting her.  In silence, VICTORIA steps up and takes her place at the hea of the table. At last, PONSONBY leans forward deferentially.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I say, how glad I am to see Your Majesty so much recovered. VICTORIA nods, then turns and looks about at the others.  PRINCESS ALEXANDRA is seated at the far end of the table. VICTORIA frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is my son?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prince Albert is at Windsor, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is he not here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is sick, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why are you not with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ordered all members of the Royal Family to attend you at Balmoral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is the matter with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has typhoid fever, ma'am. VICTORIA stares blankly at DOCTOR JENNER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  You are mistaken.  Prince Albert, my husband, had typhoid fever.  I asked what was wrong with my son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same, your Majesty. VICTORIA stops.  She stares down the length of the table. A long pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why was I not informed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did not consider it wise, in the circumstances, to tax your nerves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How ill is he? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Alexandra)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is not well, ma'am. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must go to him. Suddenly, VICTORIA stands.  Chairs bang back as everyone leaps to their feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must leave at once. Abruptly, VICTORIA turns for the door and the room erupts into activity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BROWN stands in the corridor, a little nonplussed by the servants and Householders hurrying about in every direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half an hour later, BROWN races up to the Queen's carriag amid a swarm of servants, ladies' maids and Householders rushing to be ready in time. Suddenly the huge castle doors open and VICTORIA bustles out with her entourage in tow.  BROWN -- only just in tim - yanks open the door for VICTORIA to step past him and take her place.  She ignores him completely. BROWN slams the doors.  As he looks up, he sees his broth ARCHIE staring at him from across the courtyard.  For a second the two brothers hold each other's gaze.  It's obvious that ARCHIE has noticed the Queen's indifference. BROWN turns away and mounts the box as the carriage races away under him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some days later.  A tableau. QUEEN VICTORIA sits at the foot of the bed, a matriarch surrounded by her ROYAL FAMILY.  They watch DOCTOR JENNER bend to examine the ghostly figure of BERTIE.  He listens for a pulse.  Finally, he looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better. VICTORIA lets out a deep breath.  She takes hold of PRINCESS ALEXANDRA'S hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should the good Lord see fit to spare my son, I will order a mass to be celebrated at St. George's.  The people must share with their Queen, her prayers and hopes for their future King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few minutes later, BROWN stands in the corridor when th door bursts open and VICTORIA marches straight past him with PONSONBY at her side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aside to BROWN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen will be riding to St. George's on the fifth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (launching straight in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I recommend Her Majesty uses the covered carriage with a full Horse Guard.  In the event of any disturbance I will ensure --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cutting in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will ride to St. George's in an open carriage.  It is time the Queen was seen by her public. VICTORIA turns and disappears down the corridor, followed by PONSONBY.  We linger on BROWN'S humiliation, closer an closer until ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some weeks later. A series of angles on BROWN as he walks amid the mass of onlookers pressing against a cordon of guards surrounding the cathedral.  All the time, his eyes flick left and right, searching the faces in front of him for potential assassins.  Over his intense watchfulness we hear ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... praise and magnify thy glorious name for that thou has raised thy servant Albert Edward, Prince of Wales from the bed of sickness.  We pray thee to perfect the recovery of thy servant and to crown him day by day with more abundant blessings both for body and soul, through Jesus Christ our Lord ... The CONGREGATION mutters a vast ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VICTORIA and other members of the ROYAL FAMILY walk down the steps towards the cheering crowd.  As DEAN WELLSELLY and BROWN follow, BROWN sees ARTHUR O'CONNER break from t onlookers, pulling out a gun.  BROWN yells out:

dialogues.speaker: NO
dialogues.text: He races toward O'CONNER and hits him flying, bangs him t the ground and twists the gun out of his hand.  As they fall we hear laughter and:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So there he is, Arthur O'Conner...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a few days later and BERTIE is entertaining a privat dinner party.  They include QUEEN VICTORIA, PRINCESS ALEXANDRA, PRINCESS LOUISE and HENRY PONSONBY.  BROWN is attendance.  He stands off to one side, near the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bristling with confidence)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... all seven stone of the man, paddling madly towards us through a sea of Horse Guards, waving something that looks vaguely like a pen.  I thought he must be one of the mother's ardent readership in search of the Royal indenture... More chortling.  VICTORIA watches her son, smiling proudl BROWN looks straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe I saw him first and then alerted Brown.  I'm not convinced that he wasn't taking a snooze on top of the box.  Anyway, we had our man pinned down and I must say, Brown acquitted himself admirably.  Of course the gun was a fake, but all the same, it was well done. No-one registers BROWN.  But while VICTORIA does not look at him, she is acutely aware of his presence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I intend Brown to be rewarded with a special medal cast in gold.  It will be called The Devoted Service Medal. The guests applaud politely.  BERTIE clinks his glass for attention and raises it high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A toast.  Victoria Regina! The others raise their glasses in unison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victoria Regina! VICTORIA smiles.  BROWN remains alone by the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people of England have expressed in a manner which cannot be mistaken, that they will uphold the ancient monarchy of England ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DISRAELI is delivering his come-back speech at a banquet Tory delegates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... If the first great object of the Tory Party is to maintain the institutions of the country, the second is, in my opinion, to maintain the Empire of England ... the hereditary, the traditionary policy of the Tory Party.  Go to your homes, teach them these truths, which will soon be imprinted on the conscience of the land ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of rain driven hard against a window.  We creep slowly down the corridor until we are back with the fifty year-old BROWN.  With his whiskey for company, he is sitting at his desk, writing in the diary. The diary-manuscript is now falling apart with wear, but there remain a few blank pages.  Slowly, he fills them in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should not live in expectation of contentment.  Fifteen years of vigilance will not guarantee peace of mind.  Yesterday, intruders were again reported in the South Wing.  I believe my prompt arrival may have averted any crisis, but it was a timely reminder.  It is a great comfort to me that my efforts in securing the Queen's safety over the years have not been in vain.  Certainly Her Majesty sends me no word that she's dissatisfied.  And I feel sure that if she were unhappy she would have found the occasion  to speak to me in person, as she has so often done in the past. A knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? We hear a young PAGE, breathless from running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: North woods, sir. BROWN grabs his gun and rushes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BROWN appears at the door and strides into the storm.  He walks quickly across the wide quadrangle, rain soaking hi hair and clothes. Two GUARDS watch BROWN as he races out into the storm. A coin flips through the air to be caught by an outstretched hand.  The second GUARD grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BROWN races across the open ground towards the forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now we are back with the opening sequence.  Truncated severe, and shot from a slightly different angle.  The driving rain, BROWN hurtling through the trees, the crack to his left, he spins and plunges on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close-up on BROWN as he bangs against a tree, heaving for air.  He searches the dark, stops, listens and races on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BROWN tears through the trees, pistol raised at full arm' length.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bursts into a clearing, breaks to the centre and stops Pistol raised, he turns a circle, eyes on the wildly swaying trees.  A branch snaps behind him.  He spins roun bellows deep from his heart:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God save the Queen!! And fires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few days later. VICTORIA is moving swiftly down a long corridor with LADY ELY.  They arrive at a door.  VICTORIA stands facing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long has he been this sick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few days, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why was I not told earlier? LADY ELY doesn't answer.  VICTORIA knows anyway.  She nod LADY ELY knocks.  The door is opened by a young UNDER SERVANT who gawps at the sight of Her Majesty standing he in the servant's quarters.  VICTORIA walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room has been cleared of bottles, but the thinness of the life here shocks her deeply.  The cheap furniture, th anonymous prints, the bed and, finally, the sight of BROW He is lying in bed, barely conscious.  After a moment, he opens his eyes and stares at her.  She steps forward, smiling nervously. Her voice is the old voice, between friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should never have gone out in such foul weather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone has to look after you. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could've been someone.  It was before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Yes it was. He cannot speak.  It's difficult for her too, but she speaks for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Ministers are as impertinent as ever.  Dispatches are now so numerous, they come in a trunk.  Sometimes I do believe they will never stop.  Endless letters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her voice falters.  A pause

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know I have not always been the loyal friend you deserved, John.  And yet here I am now, even now, feeling desperate at the thought of losing you. She starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be silly, woman. His old, familiar gruffness makes her smile and she pulls herself together.  Seeing a bowl of water on the side table, she steps across.  Carefully folding a cloth in four, she rinses it in the water and gently wipes his fac Leaning closer, she is about to touch his face when BROWN gestures protectively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not too near.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A week later.  PONSONBY and JENNER stand at the window overlooking the grounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Erysipelas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not too protracted, I hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few days... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he heard, the Prince of Wales threw the bust from the window of the Royal Gallery.  It took four hours to gather the fragments. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Queen wishes to publish an account of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear oh dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We think she can be dissuaded. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you had a glance at the diary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'd best take it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. He brings out BROWN'S tatty diary-manuscript and hands it over to PONSONBY.  The two men move away from the window, to go their separate ways.  Daily business beckons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you find it by the way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some young page was boasting about having seen it. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky. JENNER nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, no rest for the wicked, Henry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, indeed. The two men head off in opposite directions down the corridor.
